awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Hydrodynamic Thermal Transport in Graphitic Materials
awd_abstract_narration:
Graphitic materials exhibit some of the highest thermal conductivity values found in solids. This feature has resulted in existing and emerging applications of these materials for transferring heat and keeping operating devices cool. However, the actual mechanisms behind their high thermal conductivity are not well understood. Recent theoretical studies have suggested that frequent scattering among a peculiar group of high-population phonons in graphitic materials does not either cause resistance directly or limit their thermal conductivity contribution. This unusual phonon transport behavior has been referred as hydrodynamic phonon transport. Observation of hydrodynamic phonon transport has never been experimentally observed in any materials at a sufficiently high temperature that is relevant to technological applications. Hydrodynamic phonon transport can have practical implications in the design and thermal modeling of graphitic materials. Thus, a set of theoretically guided advanced experiments are conducted in this research to verify the existence of the unusual thermal transport behavior in graphitic materials. Also, the research findings and methods are integrated into three undergraduate and graduate courses and two demonstration modules for general public. 

The objective of this research is to elucidate the influence of hydrodynamic phonon transport on the thermal transport properties of graphitic materials. This will be accomplished through theoretical and experimental efforts, including first principles based theoretical studies of phonon transport, nanoscale thermal transport measurements of the intrinsic thermal conductance, and ultrafast opto-thermal measurements of second sound in isotopically purified nanotube, graphene, and thin graphite samples. These theoretical and experimental efforts can further lead to a better understanding of the quantum theory of energy transport by lattice vibrations. If successful, the research can lead to a new approach to simulate phonon transport. In addition, it can advance the frontier of nanoscale thermal transport measurements by overcoming a critical challenge in probing the intrinsic thermal transport properties of nanostructures. Moreover, it can result in a cutting edge ultrafast thermal transport method for probing phonon transport.

por.por_cntn:
As the energy quanta of lattice vibration in a solid, phonons scatter among themselves via normal (N) and Umklapp (U) processes that conserve and destroy phonon momentum, respectively. The resistivity to heat flow is caused by the Umklapp processes and momentum-non-conserving phonon scattering by surface and interior defects. When these resistive scattering processes are dominant, phonon transport is in the diffusive regime described by Fourier's law. When the sample size is smaller than the mean free paths of phonon-phonon scattering, phonon transport is in the ballistic regime. In comparison to the diffusive and ballistic regimes, phonon hydrodynamics describes a peculiar transport regime that is dominated by N-processes. In the hydrodynamic phonon transport regime and upon pulse heating that is faster than the U-processes but slower than the N-processes, a fluctuating temperature field can propagate in the form of a wave with minimal damping, referred as second sound as an analogue to sound wave propagation in a gas as a pressure fluctuation field due to momentum-conserving intermolecular scattering. In the hydrodynamic phonon transport regime, phonon hydrodynamic viscosity associated with frequent N-scattering can increase the phonon-boundary scattering mean free paths and thermal conductance of a rod sample above the ballistic transport limit due to  momentum-conserving random walk of phonons. Hydrodynamic phonon transport has received a renewed interest in recent years because first-principles-based calculations predicted phonon hydrodynamics in graphitic materials and other two-dimensional (2D) materials near room temperature that is relevant to technological applications.

In this project, we have devised a heat-pulse experiment that is guided by a full solution of the Peierls-Boltzmann transport equation with ab initio inputs to capture the propagation of the second sound in graphite. Below 100 K, both our measurements and theoretical calculation observed transient cooling of the lattice near the adiabatic center of a 15 mm diameter ring that is irradiated by a picosecond laser through a pair of axicon lens. Such lattice cooling cannot occur in either the diffusive or the ballistic transport regime. In the diffusive regime, the pump beam results in a temperature rise that propagates in space and decays in time. In the ballistic regime, different phonon polarizations give rise to the propagation of discrete heat pulses that only increases the lattice temperature. In comparison, in the purely hydrodynamic regime where the total momentum of phonons is conserved, the temperature field fluctuates between positive and negative displacements without any damping, similar to the pressure fluctuation during sound propagation in gas. The negative temperature displacement provides an unambiguous evidence of phonon hydrodynamics caused by dominant normal scattering processes in graphite at temperatures between 80 and 120 K.

 In addition, it is intriguing whether hydrodynamic feature influences the thermal transport properties of ultrathin graphite samples with nanometer scale thickness. While much progress has been made in sensitive thermal transport measurements of nanostructures, thermal transport measurement of ultrathin graphite and graphene remains a challenging task. In this project, we have established a four-probe thermal measurement method to measure the intrinsic thermal resistance of suspended few-layer graphene and ultrathin graphite samples as well as the extrinsic thermal contact resistance between the sample and measurement device.

The ultrafast and nanoscale thermal transport measurement methods and their findings are relevant to the exploration of graphitic nanomaterials for thermal management. Besides providing training opportunities for two PhD students to complete their PhD degrees and two undergraduate students to learn advanced thermal measurements, the research has produced example materials for integration with undergraduate and graduate heat transfer courses, as well as hands-on experimental modules for use in campus-wide outreach activities to K-12 students.
